info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 6:38AM EDT until July 13 at 2:32AM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Connecticut...Massachusetts... Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hampden and Hartford Counties. Connecticut River ABOVE Holyoke Dam affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River Below Holyoke affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex Counties. Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County. Farmington River At Simsbury affecting Hartford County. West Deerfield River AT West Deerfield affecting Franklin County. For the Connecticut River...including Holyoke, Middle Haddam, Hartford, Thompsonville, Montague, Holyoke Dam, Northampton... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Deerfield River...including West Deerfield...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Connecticut River at Montague. * WHEN...Until early Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 35.0 feet, Flooding will expand into portions of Montague and Greenfield downstream through Sunderland and Whately. Some residential areas may become inundated and localized road closures may be needed. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:01 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 31.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 28.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:01 AM EDT Tuesday was 31.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 34.8 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 28.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 34.9 feet on 05/05/1940. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 315 PM EDT.
